# Pokhran-II

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

_Pokhran-II_  
_Operation Shakti_  
---  
[![ShaktiBomb.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2a/ShaktiBomb.jpg/280px-
ShaktiBomb.jpg)](/wiki/File:ShaktiBomb.jpg) A
[cylindrical](/wiki/Cylinder_\(geometry\) "Cylinder \(geometry\)") shaped
nuclear bomb, _Shakti I_ , prior to its detonation.  
Information  
Country | India  
Test site | [Pokhran Test Range](/wiki/Pokhran_Test_Range "Pokhran Test Range"), [Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan "Rajasthan")  
Period | 11–13 May 1998  
Number of tests | 5  
Test type | [Underground tests](/wiki/Underground_nuclear_testing "Underground nuclear testing")  
Device type | Fission/fusion  
Max. yield | 43–45 [kilotons of TNT](/wiki/TNT_equivalent "TNT equivalent") (180–190 TJ) tested[1]  
Test chronology  
← Pokhran-I (_Operation[Smiling Buddha](/wiki/Smiling_Buddha "Smiling
Buddha")_)  
  
**Pokhran-II** was the series of five [nuclear bomb](/wiki/Nuclear_bomb
"Nuclear bomb") [test explosions](/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_testing "Nuclear
weapons testing") conducted by India at the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army
"Indian Army")'s [Pokhran Test Range](/wiki/Pokhran "Pokhran") in May 1998.[2]
It was the second Indian nuclear test; the first test, code-named _[Smiling
Buddha](/wiki/Smiling_Buddha "Smiling Buddha")_ , was conducted in May
1974.[3]

_Pokhran-II_ consisted of five detonations, of which the first was a [fusion
bomb](/wiki/Fusion_bomb "Fusion bomb") and the remaining four were [fission
bombs](/wiki/Fission_bomb "Fission bomb").[2] These nuclear tests resulted in
a [variety of sanctions](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1172
"United Nations Security Council Resolution 1172") against India by a number
of major states, including Japan and the United States.[4]

On 11 May 1998, **Operation Shakti** (Pokhran-II) was initiated with the
detonation of one fusion and two fission bombs; the word
"_[Shakti](/wiki/Shakti "Shakti")_ " ([Devanagari](/wiki/Devanagari
"Devanagari"): **शक्ति**) means "power" in
[Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_literature "Sanskrit literature").[2] On 13 May
1998, two additional fission devices were detonated,[5] and the [Indian
government](/wiki/Premiership_of_Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Premiership of Atal
Bihari Vajpayee") led by [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime
Minister of India") [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal
Bihari Vajpayee") shortly convened a press conference to declare India a full-
fledged nuclear state.[5]

Many names are attributed to these tests; originally they were called
**Operation Shakti–98** (_Power–98_), and the five nuclear bombs were
designated _Shakti-I_ through _Shakti-V_. More recently, the operation as a
whole has come to be known as **Pokhran II** , and the 1974 explosion as
**Pokhran-I**.[5]

## India's nuclear bomb project[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: India's nuclear bomb project")]

Efforts towards building the [nuclear bomb](/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear
weapon"), infrastructure, and research on related
[technologies](/wiki/Nuclear_technology "Nuclear technology") has been
undertaken by India since [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").
Origins of [India's nuclear program](/wiki/Indian_nuclear_programme "Indian
nuclear programme") dates back to 1944 when [nuclear
physicist](/wiki/Nuclear_Physics "Nuclear Physics") [Homi
Bhabha](/wiki/Homi_J._Bhabha "Homi J. Bhabha") began persuading the [Indian
Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") towards
harnessing of the [nuclear energy](/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_India "Nuclear power
in India")— a year later he established the [Tata Institute of Fundamental
Research](/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research "Tata Institute of
Fundamental Research") (TIFR).

In 1950s, the preliminary studies were carried out at the
[BARC](/wiki/Bhabha_Atomic_Research_Centre "Bhabha Atomic Research Centre")
and plans were developed to produce [plutonium](/wiki/Plutonium "Plutonium")
and other [bomb](/wiki/Bomb "Bomb") components. In 1962, India and
[China](/wiki/Peoples_Republic_of_China "Peoples Republic of China")
[engaged](/wiki/Sino-Indian_War "Sino-Indian War") in the disputed [northern
front](/wiki/Northern_India "Northern India"), and was further intimidated
with [Chinese](/wiki/Peoples_Republic_of_China "Peoples Republic of China")
[nuclear test](/wiki/596_\(nuclear_test\) "596 \(nuclear test\)") in 1964.
Direction towards [militarisation](/wiki/Militarisation "Militarisation") of
the [nuclear program](/wiki/Indian_nuclear_programme "Indian nuclear
programme") slowed down when [Vikram Sarabhai](/wiki/Vikram_Sarabhai "Vikram
Sarabhai") became its head and little interest of [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India") [Lal
Bahadur Shastri](/wiki/Lal_Bahadur_Shastri "Lal Bahadur Shastri") in 1965.

After [Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi") became [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India") in 1966,
the [nuclear program](/wiki/Indian_nuclear_programme "Indian nuclear
programme") was consolidated when [physicist](/wiki/Physics "Physics") [Raja
Ramanna](/wiki/Raja_Ramanna "Raja Ramanna") joined the efforts. Another
[nuclear test](/wiki/Test_No._6 "Test No. 6") by
[China](/wiki/Peoples_Republic_of_China "Peoples Republic of China")
eventually led to India's decision toward building [nuclear
weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon") in 1967 and conducted its
first nuclear test, [Smiling Buddha](/wiki/Smiling_Buddha "Smiling Buddha"),
in 1974.[6]

### Post-Smiling Buddha[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Post-Smiling Buddha")]

Responding to Smiling Buddha, the [Nuclear Suppliers
Group](/wiki/Nuclear_Suppliers_Group "Nuclear Suppliers Group") severely
affected the [India's nuclear
program](/wiki/India_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "India and weapons of
mass destruction").[7] The world's [major nuclear powers](/wiki/G8 "G8")
imposed [technological embargo](/wiki/Technological_apartheid "Technological
apartheid") on [India and Pakistan](/wiki/India_and_Pakistan "India and
Pakistan"), which was technologically racing to meet with India's
challenge.[7] The [nuclear
program](/wiki/India_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "India and weapons of
mass destruction") struggled for years to gain credibility and its progress
crippled by the lack of indigenous resources and dependent on imported
technology and technical assistance.[7] At
[IAEA](/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency "International Atomic Energy
Agency"), [Prime Minister](/wiki/Indian_Prime_Minister "Indian Prime
Minister") [Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi") declared that
India's nuclear program was not militarising despite authorising preliminary
work on the [hydrogen bomb](/wiki/Teller-Ulam_design "Teller-Ulam design")
design.[7]

As an aftermath of the [state emergency](/wiki/The_Emergency_\(India\) "The
Emergency \(India\)") in 1975 that resulted in the
[collapse](/wiki/Government_failure "Government failure") of the Prime
Minister Indira Gandhi's [government](/wiki/Second_Indira_Gandhi_ministry
"Second Indira Gandhi ministry"), the nuclear program was left with a vacuum
of political leadership and even basic management.[7] Work on the hydrogen
bomb design continued under [M. Srinivasan](/wiki/M.R._Srinivasan "M.R.
Srinivasan"), a [mechanical engineer](/wiki/Mechanical_engineering "Mechanical
engineering"), but progress was slow.[7]

The nuclear program received little attention from Prime Minister [Morarji
Desai](/wiki/Morarji_Desai "Morarji Desai") who was renowned for his [peace
advocacy](/wiki/Gandhism "Gandhism").[7] In 1978, Prime Minister Desai
transferred [physicist](/wiki/Physicist "Physicist")
[Ramanna](/wiki/Raja_Ramanna "Raja Ramanna") to [Indian
MoD](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_\(India\) "Ministry of Defence \(India\)"), and
[his government](/wiki/Premiership_of_Morarji_Desai "Premiership of Morarji
Desai") was not entirely without progress in [nuclear
program](/wiki/India_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "India and weapons of
mass destruction") and had the program continue to grow at a desirable
rate.[7][8]

Disturbing news came from Pakistan when the world discovered the [Pakistan's
clandestine atomic bomb
program](/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Pakistan and weapons
of mass destruction").[7] Contrary to India's nuclear program, Pakistan's
atomic bomb program was akin to United States's [Manhattan
Project](/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project"), it was under military
oversight with civilian scientists in charge of the scientific aspects of the
program.[7] The Pakistani atomic bomb program was well funded and organised by
then; India realised that Pakistan was likely to succeed in its project in
matter of two years.[7]

In 1980, the [general elections](/wiki/Indian_general_election,_1980 "Indian
general election, 1980") marked the return of Indira Gandhi and the nuclear
program began to gain momentum under Ramanna in 1981. Requests for additional
[nuclear tests](/wiki/Nuclear_test "Nuclear test") were continued to be denied
by the [government](/wiki/Third_Indira_Gandhi_ministry "Third Indira Gandhi
ministry") when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi saw Pakistan began exercising the
[_brinkmanship_](/wiki/Nuclear_brinksmanship "Nuclear brinksmanship"), though
the nuclear program continued to advance.[7] Initiation towards hydrogen bomb
began as well as the launch of the [missile
programme](/wiki/Indian_Missile_Program "Indian Missile Program") began under
Late president [Dr.Abdul Kalam](/wiki/Avul_Pakir_Jainulabdeen_Abdul_Kalam
"Avul Pakir Jainulabdeen Abdul Kalam"), who was then an [aerospace
engineer](/wiki/Aerospace_engineering "Aerospace engineering").[7]

## Political momentum: 1988–1998[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Political momentum: 1988–1998")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ab_vajpayee.jpg/200px-
Ab_vajpayee.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ab_vajpayee.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ab_vajpayee.jpg "Enlarge")

During the [1998 Indian general election](/wiki/Indian_general_election,_1998
"Indian general election, 1998"), [BJP](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party
"Bharatiya Janata Party")'s [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee
"Atal Bihari Vajpayee") promised to carry out nuclear tests.

In 1989, the [general elections](/wiki/Indian_general_election,_1989 "Indian
general election, 1989") witnessed the [Janata Dal](/wiki/Janata_Dal "Janata
Dal"), the [right-wing](/wiki/Hindu_right "Hindu right") party led by [V.P.
Singh](/wiki/Vishwanath_Pratap_Singh "Vishwanath Pratap Singh"), forming the
[government](/wiki/V._P._Singh_ministry "V. P. Singh ministry").[9] [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India") [V.P.
Singh](/wiki/Vishwanath_Pratap_Singh "Vishwanath Pratap Singh") down played
the [relations](/wiki/India-Pakistan_Relations "India-Pakistan Relations")
with the [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan "Prime Minister of
Pakistan") [Benazir Bhutto](/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto "Benazir Bhutto") whose
[Pakistan Peoples Party](/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party "Pakistan Peoples
Party") (PPP) won the [general
elections](/wiki/Pakistani_general_elections,_1988 "Pakistani general
elections, 1988") in 1988. [Foreign relations](/wiki/India-Pakistan_Relations
"India-Pakistan Relations") between India and Pakistan began to severely
worsen when India began charging Pakistan of supporting the
[militancy](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and
Kashmir") in [Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir "Jammu and
Kashmir").[9] During this time, the [missile
program](/wiki/Indian_Missile_Program "Indian Missile Program") succeeded in
the development of the [_Prithvi_](/wiki/Prithvi_\(missile\) "Prithvi
\(missile\)") [missiles](/wiki/Missile "Missile").

Successive governments in India decided to observe this temporary moratorium
for fear of inviting international criticism.[7] The Indian public had been
supportive towards the [nuclear tests](/wiki/Nuclear_test "Nuclear test")
which ultimately led [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime
Minister of India") [Narasimha Rao](/wiki/P.V._Narasimha_Rao "P.V. Narasimha
Rao") deciding to conduct further tests in 1995.[9] Plans were halted after
American [spy satellites](/wiki/Evolved_Enhanced_CRYSTAL "Evolved Enhanced
CRYSTAL") picked up signs of preparations for [nuclear
testing](/wiki/Nuclear_testing "Nuclear testing") at [Pokhran Test
Range](/wiki/Pokhran_Test_Range "Pokhran Test Range") in
[Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan "Rajasthan").[9]
[President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") and his
[administration](/wiki/Clinton_administration "Clinton administration")
exerted enormous pressure on [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India
"Prime Minister of India") [Narasimha Rao](/wiki/P.V._Narasimha_Rao "P.V.
Narasimha Rao") to stop the preparations.[9] Responding to India, [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan "Prime Minister of Pakistan")
[Benazir Bhutto](/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto "Benazir Bhutto") issued harsh and
severe statements against India on Pakistan's [news
channels](/wiki/News_channels_in_Pakistan "News channels in Pakistan"); thus
putting stress on the [relations](/wiki/India-Pakistan_Relations "India-
Pakistan Relations") between [two countries](/wiki/India_and_Pakistan "India
and Pakistan").[10]

Diplomatic tension escalated between [two countries](/wiki/India_and_Pakistan
"India and Pakistan") when [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan
"Prime Minister of Pakistan") [Benazir Bhutto](/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto "Benazir
Bhutto") raised the [Kashmir issue](/wiki/Kashmir_problem "Kashmir problem")
at the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") in 1995.[11] In
a speech delivered by then-[Speaker National
Assembly](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Pakistan "Speaker of the
National Assembly of Pakistan") [Yousaf Raza
Gillani](/wiki/Yousaf_Raza_Gillani "Yousaf Raza Gillani"), stressed the
"[Kashmir issue](/wiki/Kashmir_problem "Kashmir problem")" as continue to
endanger the peace and security in the region.[11] The Indian delegation
headed by [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari
Vajpayee") at the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"),
reiterated that the "UN resolutions only call upon Pakistan— the occupying
force to vacate the "Jammu and Kashmir Area."[11]

### 1998 Indian general elections[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: 1998 Indian general elections")]

Main articles: [Indian general election,
1998](/wiki/Indian_general_election,_1998 "Indian general election, 1998");
[Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata
Party"); [Indian economy](/wiki/Indian_economy "Indian economy"); and [Indian
politics](/wiki/Indian_politics "Indian politics")

The [BJP](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party"), came to
power in [1998 general elections](/wiki/Indian_general_election,_1998 "Indian
general election, 1998") with an exclusive [public
mandate](/wiki/Exclusive_mandate "Exclusive mandate").[5] BJP's political
might have been growing steadily in strength over the past decade over several
issues.

In Pakistan, the similar [conservative force](/wiki/Conservatism_in_Pakistan
"Conservatism in Pakistan"), the [PML(N)](/wiki/Pakistan_Muslim_League_\(N\)
"Pakistan Muslim League \(N\)"), was also in [power](/wiki/Power_\(politics\)
"Power \(politics\)") with an [exclusive mandate](/wiki/Exclusive_mandate
"Exclusive mandate") led by [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan
"Prime Minister of Pakistan") [Nawaz Sharif](/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif "Nawaz
Sharif") who defeated the [leftist](/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan "Socialism in
Pakistan") [PPP](/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party "Pakistan Peoples Party") led by
[Benazir Bhutto](/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto "Benazir Bhutto") in [general
elections](/wiki/Pakistani_general_election,_1997 "Pakistani general election,
1997") held in 1997.[12] During the [BJP](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party
"Bharatiya Janata Party") campaign, [Atal Bihari
Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee") indulged in
grandstanding— such as when he declared on 25 February that his government
would "take back that [part of Kashmir](/wiki/Pakistan_Kashmir "Pakistan
Kashmir") that is under Pakistan's control."[5] Before this declaration, the
[BJP platform](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") had
clear intention to "exercise the option to induct nuclear weapons" and "India
should become an openly nuclear power to garner the respect on the world stage
that India deserved."[5] By 18 March 1998, Vajpayee had publicly begun his
lobbying for [nuclear explosion](/wiki/Nuclear_explosion "Nuclear explosion")
and declared that "there is no compromise on national security; all options
including the nuclear options will be exercised to protect security and
sovereignty."[5]

Consultation began between [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India
"Prime Minister of India") [Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari
Vajpayee"), [Dr.Abdul Kalam](/wiki/APJ_Abdul_Kalam "APJ Abdul Kalam"), [R.
Chidambaram](/wiki/R._Chidambaram "R. Chidambaram") and officials of the
[Indian DAE](/wiki/Department_of_Atomic_Energy_\(India\) "Department of Atomic
Energy \(India\)") on nuclear options. [Chidambaram](/wiki/R._Chidambaram "R.
Chidambaram") briefed [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime
Minister of India") [Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari
Vajpayee") extensively on the [nuclear program](/wiki/Indian_nuclear_programme
"Indian nuclear programme"); [Abdul Kalam](/wiki/APJ_Abdul_Kalam "APJ Abdul
Kalam") presented the status of the [missile
program](/wiki/Indian_Missile_Program "Indian Missile Program"). On 28 March
1998, [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of
India") [Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee") asked
the scientists to make preparations in the shortest time possible, and
preparations were hastily made.[13]

It was time of tense atmosphere when Pakistan, at a [Conference on
Disarmament](/wiki/Conference_on_Disarmament "Conference on Disarmament"),
offered a peace rhetoric agreement with India for "an equal and mutual
restraint in conventional, missile and nuclear fields."[5] Pakistan's equation
was later reemphasised on 6 April and the momentum in India for nuclear tests
began to build up which strengthened Vajpayee's position to order the
tests.[5]

### Preparations for the test[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Preparations for the test")]

Main articles: [CIA activities in India](/wiki/CIA_activities_in_India "CIA
activities in India"), [ISI activities in India](/wiki/ISI_activities_in_India
"ISI activities in India"), and [Indo-US Relations](/wiki/Indo-US_Relations
"Indo-US Relations")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Tracking_Nuclear_Proliferation%2C_India.jpg/250px-
Tracking_Nuclear_Proliferation%2C_India.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tracking_Nuclear_Proliferation,_India.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tracking_Nuclear_Proliferation,_India.jpg "Enlarge")

The [US Marine Intelligence](/wiki/Marine_Corps_Intelligence_Activity "Marine
Corps Intelligence Activity") maps showing the Indian test site, 1997.

Unlike Pakistan's [weapon–testing laboratories](/wiki/Nuclear_test_site
"Nuclear test site"), there was very little that India could do to hide its
activity at [Pokhran](/wiki/Pokhran "Pokhran").[14] Contrary to [high-
altitude](/wiki/High-altitude_platform "High-altitude platform") [granite
mountains](/wiki/Mountain_ranges_of_Pakistan "Mountain ranges of Pakistan") in
Pakistan, the bushes are sparse and the dunes in the [Rajasthan
Desert](/wiki/Rajasthan_Desert "Rajasthan Desert") don't provide much cover
from [probing satellites](/wiki/Surveillance_satellite "Surveillance
satellite").[14] The [Indian intelligence](/wiki/Indian_Intelligence_Agency
"Indian Intelligence Agency") had been aware of United States [spy
satellites](/wiki/Nuclear_MASINT "Nuclear MASINT") and the [American
CIA](/wiki/American_CIA "American CIA") had been detecting Indian test
preparations since 1995; therefore, the tests required complete
[secrecy](/wiki/Secrecy "Secrecy") in India and also needed to avoid detection
by other countries.[14] The [58th Engineer
Regiment](/wiki/Indian_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "Indian Army Corps of
Engineers") of [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army")'s [Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/Indian_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "Indian Army Corps of
Engineers") was commissioned to prepare the test sites without being probed by
the United States [spy satellites](/wiki/Nuclear_MASINT "Nuclear MASINT"). The
58th Engineer's commander [Colonel](/wiki/Colonel "Colonel") Gopal Kaushik
supervised the test preparations and ordered his "staff officers take all
measures to ensure total secrecy."[14]

Extensive planning was done by a very small group of scientists, senior
military officers and senior politicians to ensure that the test preparations
would remain secret, and even senior members of the [Indian
government](/wiki/Indian_government "Indian government") didn't know what was
going on. The chief scientific adviser and the director of
[DRDO](/wiki/Defence_Research_and_Development_Organisation "Defence Research
and Development Organisation"), [Dr.Abdul Kalam](/wiki/A.P.J._Abdul_Kalam
"A.P.J. Abdul Kalam"), and Dr. [R. Chidambaram](/wiki/R._Chidambaram "R.
Chidambaram"), the director of the [DAE](/wiki/Department_of_Atomic_Energy
"Department of Atomic Energy"), were the chief coordinators of this test
planning.[5] The scientists and engineers of the
[BARC](/wiki/Bhabha_Atomic_Research_Centre "Bhabha Atomic Research Centre"),
the [AMDER](/wiki/Atomic_Minerals_Directorate_for_Exploration_and_Research
"Atomic Minerals Directorate for Exploration and Research"), and the
[DRDO](/wiki/Defence_Research_and_Development_Organisation "Defence Research
and Development Organisation") were involved in the nuclear weapon assembly,
layout, detonation and obtaining test data.[5] A very small group of senior
scientists were involved in the detonation process, all scientists were
required to wear army uniforms to preserve the secrecy of the tests. Since
1995, the 58th Engineer Regiment had learned to avoid satellite detection.[5]
Work was mostly done during night, and equipment was returned to the original
place to give the impression that it was never moved.[5]

Bomb shafts were dug under camouflage netting and the dug-out sand was shaped
like shaped dunes. Cables for sensors were covered with sand and concealed
using native vegetation.[5] Scientists would not depart for Pokhran in groups
of two or three.[5] They travelled to destination other than Pokhran under
pseudonyms, and were then transported by the army. Technical staff at the test
range wore military uniform, to prevent detection in satellite images.[14]

## Nuclear weapon designs and development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Nuclear weapon designs and
development")]

### Development and test teams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Development and test teams")]

The main technical personnel involved in the operation were:[1]

  * Project Chief Coordinators 
    * Dr. [A.P.J. Abdul Kalam](/wiki/A.P.J._Abdul_Kalam "A.P.J. Abdul Kalam") (later, President of India), Scientific Adviser to the prime minister and Head of the [DRDO](/wiki/DRDO "DRDO").
    * Dr. [R. Chidambaram](/wiki/Rajagopala_Chidambaram "Rajagopala Chidambaram"), Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Atomic energy.
  * [Defence Research & Development Organization](/wiki/Defence_Research_%26_Development_Organization "Defence Research & Development Organization") (DRDO) 
    * Dr. K. Santhanam; Director, Test Site Preparations.
  * [Atomic Minerals Directorate for Exploration and Research](/wiki/Atomic_Minerals_Directorate_for_Exploration_and_Research "Atomic Minerals Directorate for Exploration and Research")
    * Dr. G. R. Dikshitulu; Senior Research Scientist B.S.O.I Group, Nuclear Materials Acquisition
  * [Bhabha Atomic Research Centre](/wiki/Bhabha_Atomic_Research_Centre "Bhabha Atomic Research Centre") (BARC) 
    * Dr. [Anil Kakodkar](/wiki/Anil_Kakodkar "Anil Kakodkar"), Director of BARC.
    * Dr. [Satinder Kumar Sikka](/wiki/S._K._Sikka "S. K. Sikka"), Director; Thermonuclear Weapon Development.
    * Dr. [M. S. Ramakumar](/wiki/M._S._Ramakumar "M. S. Ramakumar"), Director of Nuclear Fuel and Automation Manufacturing Group; Director, Nuclear Component Manufacture.
    * Dr. D.D. Sood, Director of Radiochemistry and Isotope Group; Director, Nuclear Materials Acquisition.
    * Dr. S.K. Gupta, Solid State Physics and Spectroscopy Group; Director, Device Design & Assessment.
    * Dr. G. Govindraj, Associate Director of Electronic and Instrumentation Group; Director, Field Instrumentation.

### Movement and logistics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Movement and logistics")]

Main articles: [Military logistics](/wiki/Military_logistics "Military
logistics") and [Indian Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/Indian_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "Indian Army Corps of
Engineers")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/A_sunset_on_the_dunes_of_the_Great_Indian_Thar_Desert_Rajasthan_India.jpg/250px-
A_sunset_on_the_dunes_of_the_Great_Indian_Thar_Desert_Rajasthan_India.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_sunset_on_the_dunes_of_the_Great_Indian_Thar_Desert_Rajasthan_India.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_sunset_on_the_dunes_of_the_Great_Indian_Thar_Desert_Rajasthan_India.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [Thar Desert](/wiki/Thar_Desert "Thar Desert") in the state of
[Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan "Rajasthan") where the nuclear site, the [Pokhran
Test Range](/wiki/Pokhran_Test_Range "Pokhran Test Range"), is located.

Three laboratories of the [DRDO](/wiki/DRDO "DRDO") were involved in
designing, testing and producing components for the bombs, including the
advanced detonators, the implosion and high-voltage trigger systems. These
were also responsible for weaponising, systems engineering, aerodynamics,
safety interlocks and flight trials.[1] The bombs were transported in four
[Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") trucks under the command of
Colonel Umang Kapur; all devices from BARC were relocated at 3:00Hrs on 1 May
1998. From the [Chhatrapati Shivaji International
Airport](/wiki/Chhatrapati_Shivaji_International_Airport "Chhatrapati Shivaji
International Airport"), the bombs were flown in an [Indian Air
Force](/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force")'s [AN-32](/wiki/AN-32
"AN-32") plane to the Jaisalmer army base. They were transported to Pokhran in
an army convoy of four trucks, and this required three trips. The devices were
delivered to the device preparation building, which was designated as 'Prayer
Hall'.[1]

The test sites was organised into two government groups and were fired
separately, with all devices in a group fired at the same time. The first
group consisted of the thermonuclear device (_Shakti I_), the fission device
(_Shakti II_), and a sub-kiloton device (_Shakti III_). The second group
consisted of the remaining two sub-kiloton devices _Shakti IV_ and _V_. It was
decided that the first group would be tested on 11 May and the second group on
13 May. The thermonuclear device was placed in a shaft code named 'White
House', which was over 200 m deep, the fission bomb was placed in a 150 m deep
shaft code named 'Taj Mahal', and the first sub-kiloton device in
'Kumbhkaran'. The first three devices were placed in their respective shafts
on 10 May, and the first device to be placed was the sub-kiloton device in the
'Kumbhkaran' shaft, which was sealed by the army engineers by 8:30 pm. The
thermonuclear device was lowered and sealed into the 'White House' shaft by 4
am, and the fission device being placed in the 'Taj Mahal' shaft was sealed at
7:30 am, which was 90 minutes before the planned test time. The shafts were
L-shaped, with a horizontal chamber for the test device.[1]

The timing of the tests depended on the local weather conditions, with the
wind being the critical factor. The tests were underground, but due to a
number of shaft seal failures that had occurred during tests conducted by the
United States, the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), and the
United Kingdom, the sealing of the shaft could not be guaranteed to be leak-
proof. By early afternoon, the winds had died down and the test sequence was
initiated. Dr. K. Santhanam of the DRDO, in charge of the test site
preparations, gave the two keys that activated the test countdown to Dr. M.
Vasudev, the range safety officer, who was responsible for verifying that all
test indicators were normal. After checking the indicators, Vasudev handed one
key each to a representative of BARC and the DRDO, who unlocked the countdown
system together. At 3:45 pm the three devices were detonated.[1]

### Nuclear bombs and detonations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Nuclear bombs and detonations")]

Five nuclear devices were detonated during Operation Shakti.[15] All devices
were weapon-grade [plutonium](/wiki/Plutonium "Plutonium")[1] and they
were:[1]

  * Shakti I – A [thermonuclear device](/wiki/Thermonuclear_weapon "Thermonuclear weapon") yielding 45 kt, but designed for up to 200 kt.
  * Shakti II – A [plutonium implosion](/wiki/Implosion-type_nuclear_weapon "Implosion-type nuclear weapon") design yielding 15 kt and intended as a warhead that could be delivered by bomber or missile. It was an improvement of the device detonated in the 1974 [Smiling Buddha](/wiki/Smiling_Buddha "Smiling Buddha") (Pokhran-I) test of 1974, developed using simulations on the [PARAM](/wiki/PARAM "PARAM") supercomputer.
  * Shakti III – An experimental [linear implosion](/wiki/Implosion_nuclear_weapon "Implosion nuclear weapon") design that used "non-[weapon grade](/wiki/Weapons-grade "Weapons-grade")"[16] plutonium, but which likely omitted the material required for fusion, yielding 0.3 kt.
  * Shakti IV- A 0.5 kt experimental device.
  * Shakti V – A 0.2 kt experimental device.

An additional, sixth device (Shakti VI) is suspected to have been present but
not detonated.[1]

At 3:43 pm [IST](/wiki/Indian_Standard_Time "Indian Standard Time"); three
nuclear bombs (specifically, the _Shakti I_ , II and III) were detonated
simultaneously, as measured by international seismic monitors.[5] On 13 May,
at 12.21 p.m.IST 6:51 UTC, two sub-kiloton devices (_Shakti IV_ and V) were
detonated. Due to their very low yield, these explosions were not detected by
any seismic station.[5] On 13 May 1998, India declared the series of tests to
be over after this.[17]

## Reactions to the tests[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Reactions to the tests")]

### Reactions in India[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Reactions in India")]

Following the Pokhran-II tests, India became the sixth country to join the
[nuclear club](/wiki/Nuclear_club "Nuclear club").[18] Shortly after the
tests, a press meet was convened at the Prime Minister's residence in New
Delhi. Prime Minister [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal
Bihari Vajpayee") appeared before the press corps and made the following short
statement:

“ | Today, at 15:45 hours, India conducted three underground nuclear tests in the Pokhran range. The tests conducted today were with a fission device, a low yield device and a thermonuclear device. The measured yields are in line with expected values. Measurements have also confirmed that there was no release of radioactivity into the atmosphere. These were contained explosions like the experiment conducted in May 1974. I warmly congratulate the scientists and engineers who have carried out these successful tests.[19] | ”  
---|---|---  
  
News of the tests were greeted with jubilation and large-scale approval by
society in India.[20] The [Bombay Stock Exchange](/wiki/Bombay_Stock_Exchange
"Bombay Stock Exchange") registered significant gains. Newspapers and
television channels praised the government for its bold decision; editorials
were full of praise for the country's leadership and advocated the development
of an operational nuclear arsenal for the country's armed forces.[20] The
Indian opposition, led by [Congress Party](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress
"Indian National Congress") criticised the [Vajpayee
administration](/wiki/Vajpayee_Government "Vajpayee Government") for carrying
out the series of nuclear tests.[20] The Congress Party spokesman, [Salman
Khursheed](/wiki/Salman_Khursheed "Salman Khursheed"), accused the
[BJP](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janta_Party "Bharatiya Janta Party") of trying to use
the tests for political ends rather than to enhance the country's national
security.[20]

By the time India had conducted tests, the country had a total of $44bn in
loans in 1998, from [IMF](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International
Monetary Fund") and the [World Bank](/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank").[21] The
industrial sectors of the Indian economy such as the chemicals industry, were
likely to be hurt by sanctions.[21] The Western consortium companies, which
has invested heavily in India, especially in construction, computing and
telecoms, were generally the one who were harmed by the sanctions.[21] In
1998, Indian government announced that it had already allowed for some
economic response and was willing to take the consequences.[21]

### International reactions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: International reactions")]

#### United States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-II&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: United States")]

The United States issued a strong statement condemning India and promised that
[sanctions](/wiki/Economic_sanctions "Economic sanctions") would follow. The
American [intelligence community](/wiki/US_intelligence_community "US
intelligence community") was embarrassed as there had been "a serious
intelligence failure of the decade" in detecting the preparations for the
test.[22]

In keeping with its preferred approach to [foreign
policy](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_clinton_administration "Foreign policy of
the clinton administration") in [recent
decades](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1991%E2%80%93present\) "History
of the United States \(1991–present\)"), and in compliance with the [1994
anti-proliferation law](/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-
Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons "Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear
Weapons"), the United States imposed economic sanctions on India.[4] The
sanctions on India consisted of cutting off all assistance to India except
humanitarian aid, banning the export of certain defence material and
technologies, ending American credit and credit guarantees to India, and
requiring the US to oppose lending by international financial institutions to
India.[23]

From 1998–99, the United States held series of bilateral talks with India over
the issue of India becoming [party](/wiki/Party_\(politics\) "Party
\(politics\)") of the [CTBT](/wiki/Comprehensive_Test_Ban_Treaty
"Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty") and [NPT](/wiki/Non-Proliferation_Treaty
"Non-Proliferation Treaty").[24] In addition, the United States also made an
unsuccessful attempt of holding talks regarding the [rollback](/wiki/Rollback
"Rollback") of [India's nuclear program](/wiki/Indian_nuclear_programme
"Indian nuclear programme").[25] India took a firm stand against the
[CTBT](/wiki/Comprehensive_Test_Ban_Treaty "Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty")
and refusing to be signatory [party](/wiki/Party_\(politics\) "Party
\(politics\)") of it despite under pressure by the [US
President](/wiki/United_States_President "United States President") [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton"), and noted the
[treaty](/wiki/Comprehensive_Test_Ban_Treaty "Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty")
as it was not consistent with India's national security interest.[25]

#### Canada, Japan, and other states[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Canada, Japan, and other states")]

Strong criticism was drawn from Canada on India's actions and its [High
Commissioner](/wiki/List_of_Ambassadors_and_High_Commissioners_of_Canada "List
of Ambassadors and High Commissioners of Canada").[26]
[Sanctions](/wiki/Economic_sanctions "Economic sanctions") were also imposed
by Japan on India and consisted of freezing all new loans and grants except
for humanitarian aid to India.[27]

Some other nations also imposed sanctions on India, primarily in the form of
suspension of [foreign aid](/wiki/Category:Foreign_aid_to_India
"Category:Foreign aid to India") to India and government-to-government credit
lines.[28] However, the United Kingdom, France, and Russia refrained from
condemning India.[28]

#### China[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-II&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: China")]

On 12 May the Chinese Foreign Ministry stated: "The Chinese government is
seriously concerned about the nuclear tests conducted by India," and that the
tests "run counter to the current international trend and are not conducive to
peace and stability in South Asia.".[29] The next day the [Chinese Foreign
Ministry](/wiki/Chinese_Foreign_Ministry "Chinese Foreign Ministry") issued
the statement clearly stating that "it shocked and strongly condemned" the
Indian nuclear tests and called for the international community to "adopt a
unified stand and strongly demand that India immediate stop development of
nuclear weapons".[30] China further rejected India's stated rationale of
needing nuclear capabilities to counter a Chinese threat as "totally
unreasonable".[30] In a meeting with [Masayoshi
Takemura](/wiki/Masayoshi_Takemura "Masayoshi Takemura") of [Democratic Party
of Japan](/wiki/Democratic_Party_of_Japan "Democratic Party of Japan"),
[Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of
China](/wiki/Foreign_Minister_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China "Foreign
Minister of the People's Republic of China") [Qian Qichen](/wiki/Qian_Qichen
"Qian Qichen") was quoted as saying that India's nuclear tests were a "serious
matter," particularly because they were conducted in light of the fact that
more than 140 countries have signed the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. "It is
even more unacceptable that India claims to have conducted the tests to
counter what it called a _" China threat_".[30] On 24 November 1998, the
[Chinese Embassy, New
Delhi](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China
"List of diplomatic missions of the People's Republic of China") issued a
formal statement:

> (sic).... But regrettably, India conducted nuclear tests last May, which has
> run against the contemporary historical trend and seriously affected peace
> and stability in South Asia. Pakistan also conducted nuclear tests later on.
> India's nuclear tests have not only led to the escalation of tensions
> between India and Pakistan and provocation of nuclear arms races in South
> Asia, but also dealt a heavy blow to international nuclear disarmament and
> the global nonproliferation regime. It is only natural that India's nuclear
> tests have met with extensive condemnation and aroused serious concern from
> the international community.
>
> — [Chinese Embassy, New
> Delhi](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China
> "List of diplomatic missions of the People's Republic of China")[31]

#### Pakistan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-II&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Pakistan")]

Main article: [India-Pakistan relations](/wiki/India-Pakistan_relations
"India-Pakistan relations")

The most vehement and strong reaction to India's [nuclear
explosion](/wiki/Nuclear_explosion "Nuclear explosion") was from a
neighbouring country, Pakistan. Great ire was raised in Pakistan, which issued
a severe statement blaming India for instigating a [nuclear arms
race](/wiki/Nuclear_arms_race "Nuclear arms race") in the region.[5] [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan "Prime Minister of Pakistan")
[Nawaz Sharif](/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif "Nawaz Sharif") vowed that his country would
give a suitable reply to India.[5] The day after the first tests, [Foreign
Minister](/wiki/Minister_of_Foreign_Affairs_\(Pakistan\) "Minister of Foreign
Affairs \(Pakistan\)") [Gohar Ayub Khan](/wiki/Gohar_Ayub_Khan "Gohar Ayub
Khan") indicated that Pakistan was ready to conduct a nuclear test. He stated:
"Pakistan is prepared to match India, we have the capability.... We in
Pakistan will maintain a balance with India in all fields", he said in an
interview. "We are in a headlong arms race on the subcontinent."[5]

On 13 May 1998, Pakistan bitterly condemned the tests, and Foreign Minister
Gohar Ayub was quoted as saying that Indian leadership seemed to "have gone
berserk [sic] and was acting in a totally unrestrained way."[32] Prime
Minister [Nawaz Sharif](/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif "Nawaz Sharif") was much more
subdued, maintaining ambiguity about whether a test would be conducted in
response: "_We are watching the situation and we will take appropriate action
with regard to our security_ ", he said.[5] Sharif sought to mobilise the
entire [Islamic world](/wiki/Islamic_world "Islamic world") in support of
Pakistan and criticised India for [nuclear
proliferation](/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation "Nuclear proliferation").[5]

[Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan "Prime Minister of
Pakistan") [Nawaz Sharif](/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif "Nawaz Sharif") had been under
[intense pressure](/wiki/Political_pressure "Political pressure") regarding
the [nuclear tests](/wiki/Nuclear_test "Nuclear test") by
[President](/wiki/US_President "US President") [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") and [Opposition
leader](/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_\(Pakistan\) "Leader of the Opposition
\(Pakistan\)") [Benazir Bhutto](/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto "Benazir Bhutto") at
home.[33] Initially surprising the [world](/wiki/World "World"), [Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan "Prime Minister of Pakistan")
[Nawaz Sharif](/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif "Nawaz Sharif") authorised [nuclear testing
program](/wiki/Pakistan%27s_nuclear_testing_series "Pakistan's nuclear testing
series") and the [Pakistan Atomic Energy
Commission](/wiki/Pakistan_Atomic_Energy_Commission "Pakistan Atomic Energy
Commission") (PAEC) carried out nuclear testings under the codename
_[Chagai-I](/wiki/Chagai-I "Chagai-I")_ on 28 May 1998 and _[Chagai-
II](/wiki/Chagai-II "Chagai-II")_ on 30 May 1998. These six underground
nuclear tests at the [Chagai](/wiki/Ras_Koh_Hills "Ras Koh Hills") and
[Kharan](/wiki/Kharan_Desert "Kharan Desert") test site were conducted fifteen
days after India's last test. The total yield of the tests was reported to be
40 kt (see codename: _[Chagai-I](/wiki/Chagai-I "Chagai-I")_).[34]

Pakistan's subsequent tests invited similar condemnation from the United
States.[35] American President [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill
Clinton") was quoted as saying "Two wrongs don't make a right", criticising
Pakistan's tests as reactionary to India's Pokhran-II.[33] The United States
and Japan reacted by imposing economic sanctions on Pakistan. According to the
Pakistan's [science community](/wiki/Pakistan_Academy_of_Sciences "Pakistan
Academy of Sciences"), the Indian nuclear tests gave an opportunity to
Pakistan to conduct nuclear tests after 14 years of conducting only cold tests
(See: [Kirana-I](/wiki/Kirana-I "Kirana-I")).[36]

Pakistan's leading [nuclear physicist](/wiki/Nuclear_physicist "Nuclear
physicist") and one of the top scientists, Dr. [Pervez
Hoodbhoy](/wiki/Pervez_Hoodbhoy "Pervez Hoodbhoy"), held India responsible for
Pakistan's nuclear test experiments in Chagai.[37]

### U.N. sanctions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-II&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: U.N. sanctions")]

Main article: [United Nations Security Council Resolution
1172](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1172 "United Nations
Security Council Resolution 1172")

The reactions from abroad started immediately after the tests were advertised.
On 6 June, the [United Nations Security
Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security
Council") adopted [_Resolution
1172_](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1172 "United Nations
Security Council Resolution 1172") condemning the test and that of
Pakistan's.[38] China issued a vociferous condemnation calling upon the
international community to exert pressure on India to sign the NPT and
eliminate its nuclear arsenal. With India joining the group of countries
possessing nuclear weapons, a new strategic dimension had emerged in Asia,
particularly South Asia.[38]

#### Effects on Indian economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-
II&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Effects on Indian economy")]

Overall, the effect of [international sanctions](/wiki/International_sanctions
"International sanctions") on [Indian economy](/wiki/Economy_of_India "Economy
of India") was minimal; the technological progress was marginal. Most nations
did not call for [embargoes](/wiki/Embargoes "Embargoes") against India as the
exports and imports together constituted only 4.0% of its
[GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product"), with United
States trade accounting for only 10.0% of this total. Far more significant
were the restrictions on lending imposed by the United States and its
representatives on international finance bodies. Most of the sanctions were
lifted within five years.

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pokhran-II&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Legacy")]

Main article: [Public holidays in India](/wiki/Public_holidays_in_India
"Public holidays in India")

The [Indian government](/wiki/Indian_government "Indian government") has
officially declared the 11 May as National Technology Day in India to
commemorate the first of the five [nuclear tests](/wiki/Nuclear_test "Nuclear
test") that were carried out on 11 May 1998.[39]

It was officially signed by then-[Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India") [Atal
Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee") in 1998
and the day is celebrated by giving awards to various individuals and
industries in the field of science and technology.[39]
